awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Intermittency in Multi-Phase Flows in 2D and 3D Porous Media: Coordinated Experiments and Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how fluids move through porous media is of great importance.  Much of the water we rely on comes from groundwater which passes through soils.  For a significant part of our energy needs we must extract oil and gas from the subsurface.  In addition, some of the most promising proposed methods to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to the atmosphere rely on injecting CO2 back into porous media in the subsurface, where it can be trapped forever.  Similarly, many industrial processes that provide essential products or clean our air and water supplies rely on passing fluids through engineered porous media. Virtually all of these flows are complex, because they can involve multiple fluids interacting with highly heterogeneous porous geometries. While scientists have a reasonable understanding of how a single fluid might move through such systems, when two different fluids are involved our predictive skills deteriorate significantly. And yet, understanding and better predicting these flows will enhance our ability to improve access to clean water, extract and use energy resources more efficiently, protect our future environment and design more effective industrial processes. This project focuses on such complex flows. By combining state of the art experiments and theory, the investigators will develop and enhance our current understanding of multiphase flows through porous media and develop novel methods and models to predict their complex behaviors.  Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training as part of this research effort, and a high resolution, high fidelity visual teaching experience on environmental fluid mechanics will be developed in collaboration with Notre Dame's Digital Visualization Theater and shared openly with other institutions.

A coordinated experimental and numerical program will be undertaken to advance understanding of and ability to model transport in multi-phase flows in 2D and 3D porous media.  Particle tracking in both single- and multi-phase flow in 2D and 3D porous models across viscous and inertial flow regimes will be conducted leveraging a novel refractive-index-matching approach. Additionally, to enable a broader and more efficient sweep of the parameter space, a complementary series of cutting edge Lattice Boltzmann simulations, validated with experimental data, will be conducted. These innovative experiments and simulations, tightly coupled to state-of-the-art transport modeling, will validate and advance modeling strategies, transforming our understanding of intermittency in single- and multi-phase flows in 2D and 3D porous media and improving predictions of transport processes at the macro-scale for a range of engineering and environmental applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Multiphase flows in porous media are common in both engineering applications as well as the natural world. One common example is in the vadoze zone, the subsurface region below the earth surface and above the water table where air and water can co-exist within soils. This co-existence can make the structure of the flow of water through the porous soils very complex with regions of very fast flow mixed closely with regions of very slow flow. This means that dissolved substances in the flow can both move much more quickly than anticipated, but also remain trapped for much longer times than predicted with conventional approaches, which has strong implications in areas such as fertilizer management in agricultural areas and remediation of contaminated sites to name a few.

In this project we have developed a large number of high resolution numerical experiments to explore the influence of multiphase flow in porous media on how dissolved substance move and mix, relative to classical single phase settings, where only one fluid phase such as water would exist in the porous matrix. We explored a broad range of conditions varying the relative amounts of air and water (saturation) as well as the influence of considering two and three dimensional systems. Most real world applications are inherently three dimensional, but many state of the art experiments and simulations still rely on assuming two dimensions.

With this work we have been able to show that indeed transport and mixing in multiphase flows is far more complex than in a single phase setting. While this in itself is not novel, our work has been able to parse apart the specific contributions to this different behavior, meaning that we can develop a rigorous theoretical framework that builds on classical single phase knowledge and adding to it, rather than completely replacing it.

Additionally, we have shown that all of the changes in behavior that occur due to the presence of an additional phase (air) happen in both two and three-dimensional settings. However, they are much more subdued in three-dimensions, primarily because connectivity in a three dimensional system is much higher (i.e. in three dimensions there are more ways around an obstacle than two). Thus, while we can learn a great deal, we must be careful in drawing too broad a set of conclusions from idealized two-dimensional studies. Our theoretical developments provide a potential framework with which to translate two-dimensional observations to three-dimensional settings, although further work will be required to make this more robust and general.

Finally, systems with adjacent regions of very fast and very slow flow are in no way unique to multiphase flow in porous media. Indeed they are ubiquitous in many environmental settings (e.g. streams and rivers, coastal wetland, atmospheric flows over canopies to name a few). The methods that we have developed as part of this project should be translatable to such settings also, thus benefiting the broader scientific community.
